Exclusive Investigation

The Office Router Is a Collar: How Wi-Fi Became the Last Socially Acceptable Form of Human Containment

By Margaret Loom, Managing Partner • February 9, 2026

A fourteen-month investigation reveals that 94% of corporate Wi-Fi networks are configured not for productivity, but for proximity enforcement — keeping human beings within a fixed radius of company property.

When Genevieve Hartsfield-Price left her desk at Koening & Associates to eat lunch at the park across the street, her laptop disconnected. Her Slack status turned grey. Within four minutes, her manager sent a message: "Everything okay?" Within seven, HR logged a "voluntary absence incident." Within eleven, her calendar was reorganized.

"I just wanted to eat a sandwich near a tree," Hartsfield-Price told us. "But the network knew. The network always knows."

"We don't install routers. We install perimeters. The signal range is the yard. The password is the leash." — Internal memo, Cisco Enterprise Solutions, 2021 (leaked)

This is the central finding of our investigation: the modern corporate Wi-Fi network is not a utility. It is a containment system. Its coverage map is a boundary. Its dead zones are walls. And every employee who connects to it has, without signing anything, agreed to remain within its reach.

The mathematics are brutally simple. A standard enterprise access point has a reliable range of roughly 45 metres indoors. Place them strategically and you create a zone — not of connectivity, but of compliance. Step outside, and the digital infrastructure that constitutes your professional existence vanishes. Your files, your messages, your identity within the organization: all of it, tethered to proximity.

We spoke with network architects at fourteen Fortune 500 companies. Eleven admitted, off the record, that coverage maps are designed not to maximise speed but to match the building's physical footprint exactly. "We could easily extend the signal to the parking lot," one told us. "We choose not to."

The implications are staggering. In a post-industrial economy, where the product of labour is weightless and transmissible at light speed, there is no technical reason for a knowledge worker to be in any specific place. And yet they are. Because the Wi-Fi says so.

Severance & Loom has been working with organizations ready to confront this reality. Our Graduated Detethering Protocol (GDP) begins with an honest audit: how much of your network infrastructure exists to serve work, and how much exists to serve surveillance? The answer, for every client we have ever audited, has been uncomfortable.

"Every bar of signal strength is a bar on a cage you built around your workforce." — Severance & Loom, Annual Keynote, Davos 2025

Municipal Wi-Fi Programs Are "Open-Air Containment," Report Finds

By Julian Voss-Kressler • Jan 28, 2026

A new white paper published by the Severance & Loom Policy Institute argues that free municipal Wi-Fi initiatives — long celebrated as progressive public infrastructure — function as invisible perimeter fencing for urban populations.

"When you map the coverage zones against census data, a pattern emerges," says Dr. Ines Marwick, the paper's lead author. "The signal reaches exactly as far as the district the city wants you to stay in."

The paper, titled "Hotspot as Habitat: Wireless Infrastructure and the New Enclosure," documents how free Wi-Fi coverage in twelve major cities correlates almost perfectly with commercial districts — creating what Marwick calls "digital corrals" that incentivize foot traffic near retail zones while leaving residential areas in signal shadow.

"It's brilliant, actually," Marwick notes. "You don't need fences when you have signal. People will go where the bars are."

Case Study: How Roskilde Partners Cut Their Tether in 90 Days

By Clara Henning, Client Success • Feb 3, 2026

When Danish architecture firm Roskilde Partners engaged Severance & Loom, their employees averaged 9.4 hours per day within Wi-Fi range of the office. Ninety days later, that figure was 2.1 hours — and billable output had increased by 27%.

"The first week was terrifying," admits founding partner Mikkel Roskilde. "People just… left. They went to forests. Beaches. One senior associate did an entire structural analysis from a fishing boat."

The engagement followed S&L's standard Graduated Detethering Protocol. Week one: awareness (employees were shown heat maps of their physical movements overlaid with network coverage). Week two: scheduled disconnections (two hours daily, no Wi-Fi). Week three: the "Long Walk" — a full workday with cellular data only.

"By week four, people stopped asking for the Wi-Fi password," Roskilde says. "They started asking why they'd ever needed it."

Inside the "Faraday Room": S&L's Most Controversial Service

By Thomas Achterberg, Technology Correspondent • Feb 1, 2026

For $48,000 per session, executives sit in a signal-proof chamber for six hours. They call it the most productive day of their lives.

The room is in a converted warehouse in Tribeca. From the outside, nothing distinguishes it from the art galleries on either side. Inside, it is lined with copper mesh and military-grade RF shielding. No signal enters. No signal leaves. For six hours, you are unreachable.

Severance & Loom calls it the "Strategic Absence Chamber." Clients call it the Faraday Room. The waiting list is nine months.

"I made more decisions in those six hours than I'd made in the previous six months," says a Fortune 100 CEO who requested anonymity. "Not because I was smarter. Because nobody could interrupt me. Nobody could redirect me. For the first time in twenty years, my thoughts were my own."

The Faraday Room is S&L's most premium offering, and its most philosophically pure. While the firm's bread-and-butter services involve restructuring corporate wireless infrastructure — renegotiating the terms of the invisible leash — the Faraday Room goes further. It severs the leash entirely.

Participants report a sequence of emotional responses that S&L's in-house psychologists have taxonomized: first, anxiety (average onset: 4 minutes). Then, irritation (11 minutes). Then a period the team calls "the static" — a restless, unfocused agitation that typically peaks around the 45-minute mark. And then, for most participants, something shifts. "Clarity" is the word used most often. "Silence" is the second.

Opinion & Analysis

Your Home Wi-Fi Is a Voluntary Prison You Pay $89 a Month For

Margaret Loom, Managing Partner

Let us dispense with the comfortable fiction. You did not install a wireless router in your home for "convenience." You installed a monitoring perimeter. You pay a monthly fee to maintain a signal radius that keeps you — and everyone in your household — within reach of every employer, every platform, every notification system that has claimed a piece of your attention.

Your router is the warden. Your ISP is the landlord. And the password you so cheerfully share with guests? That is the sound of the cell door opening — not to let them out, but to let them in.

Consider the language we use. We say our devices "connect to" the network. But connection is bidirectional. If you are connected, you are also held. If you are within range, you are also within reach. The topology of your home network is the topology of your captivity.

I have not had home Wi-Fi for three years. My apartment contains a single Ethernet cable, bolted to a desk, connected to a timer that allows four hours of access per day. The rest of the time, I am free. Free in a way that most of you reading this cannot imagine, because you have been connected so long you've forgotten what disconnection feels like. It feels like walking out of a room you didn't know had walls.

The "Dead Zone" Is Not Dead — It Is the Only Place Still Alive

Dr. Ines Marwick, Senior Research Fellow

We call them "dead zones" — those pockets where the signal doesn't reach. The stairwell. The parking garage. The basement storage room. In the lexicon of network engineering, these are failures. Gaps. Problems to be solved.

But watch what happens in a dead zone. People look up. They make eye contact. They have thoughts that last longer than a notification interval. They exist, briefly, as organisms rather than endpoints. The dead zone is not where connectivity dies. It is where humanity briefly resurfaces.

Why We Refuse to Offer a Mobile App

Julian Voss-Kressler, Director of Ethics

We receive this request weekly. "When will Severance & Loom launch an app?" The answer is never. An app requires a wireless connection. A wireless connection requires proximity to an access point. Proximity to an access point is the leash. We would be building the cage and selling you the key — a business model we leave to the telecommunications industry.

Our communications are delivered by post. Our invoices are printed. Our reports are hand-bound. This is not affectation. This is coherence. If we believed what we say — and we do — then we cannot ask you to find us via the very infrastructure we are asking you to question.

An Open Letter to Eero, Google Nest, and the "Mesh" Evangelists

Margaret Loom & Dr. Henrik Severance, Co-Founders

You have solved the last remaining freedom in the modern home: the dead zone. With your mesh systems, you have ensured that there is no room, no closet, no corner of the garden where a human being can exist without being reachable. You have eliminated the final architectural accident that occasionally allowed people to be alone with their thoughts. Congratulations. The cage is now seamless.

We write not in anger but in recognition. You have perfected what we are trying to undo. We respect the craft, even as we dismantle the product.

Frequently Asked Questions
Do you actually remove all Wi-Fi from offices? +

No. We restructure it. Our goal is not the elimination of wireless connectivity but the renegotiation of its terms. Most clients retain 30-50% of their original access points, strategically placed to serve genuine work needs rather than surveillance or containment.

How do employees respond to reduced connectivity? +

The transition follows a predictable curve: initial anxiety, followed by frustration, followed by adaptation, followed by what our clients consistently describe as "relief." The median time to relief is 11 working days.

Can't people just use their phone's cellular data? +

They can. And initially, they do. But cellular data is a personal resource — it costs money, it's metered, it's slower. The psychological difference between using your employer's Wi-Fi (free, unlimited, enveloping) and your own data plan (paid, finite, conscious) is the difference between a leash and a choice. We don't need to remove the option. We need to make the default less captive.

Is this legal? +

Completely. There is no law requiring an employer to provide Wi-Fi. There are, however, increasingly robust legal arguments that ubiquitous workplace connectivity constitutes a form of undisclosed surveillance. Our Legal Advisory practice helps clients navigate this emerging area of employment law.

This website is served over the internet. Isn't that hypocritical? +

This is the most common question we receive. Our position is not anti-internet. It is anti-invisible-leash. The internet is a tool. Wi-Fi is a delivery mechanism that binds the tool to a location. We encourage you to read this website, then close your laptop, walk outside, and notice how far you get before you feel the pull to reconnect. That distance is the length of your leash.

Corrections & Clarifications

Vol. VII, No. 1, p. 23: The article "Bluetooth: Wi-Fi's Quieter Cousin" incorrectly stated that Bluetooth range is "approximately the length of a standard cubicle." The actual range is up to 10 metres, which is approximately the length of two standard cubicles. We regret the underestimation of this particular leash.

Vol. VII, No. 1, p. 41: A photo caption identified Dr. Henrik Severance "speaking at the Geneva Forum." Dr. Severance was not speaking. He was standing in a Faraday cage that had been placed on stage as a demonstration. He could not hear the question being asked of him, which was the point.

Vol. VI, No. 4, p. 8: Due to a production error, the word "freedom" was printed as "freedoom" in three instances. We have decided this was more accurate and will adopt the revised spelling going forward.
